title: A Single Center, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Examine the Safety and Efficacy of Pimavanserin for the Treatment of Psychosis in Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of pimavanserin 40 mg compared to placebo in patients with Alzheimer's disease psychosis.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo, two tablets, once daily by mouth

groups.title: Pimavanserin 40 mg
groups.description: Pimavanserin tartrate, 40 mg (two 20 mg tablets), once daily by mouth (equivalent to 34 mg free base pimavanserin)

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo, two tablets, once daily by mouth

groups.description: Pimavanserin tartrate, 40 mg (two 20 mg tablets), once daily by mouth (equivalent to 34 mg free base pimavanserin)

outcomeMeasures.title: Antipsychotic Efficacy
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from Baseline to Day 43 in the Neuropsychiatric Inventory-Nursing Home Version (NPI-NH) psychosis score (Delusions \[Domain A\]+Hallucinations \[Domain B\]) in the Full Analysis Set (FAS). The NPI-NH is a questionnaire that quantifies behavioral changes in dementia in nursing home patients and evaluates 12 behavioral domains. For each of the 12 behavioral domains the Frequency (scale:1=occasionally to 4=very frequently) is multiplied by the Severity (scale:1=Mild to 3=Severe) to obtain a domain score (frequency x severity), The NPI-NH Psychosis Subscale consists of the two domains of Delusions and Hallucinations, calculated by adding the Individual domain scores, to yield a possible total score of 0 to 24. Lower scores correspond to less severity. A negative change score from baseline indicates improvement.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All randomized subjects who received at least one dose of study treatment and have both a Baseline and at least one post-Baseline NPI-NH psychosis score evaluation.

adverseEventsModule.description: From the time the informed consent was signed, adverse events were recorded in the subject's source documents and entered into the appropriate eCRF pages at the Screening visit, at visits on Study Days 1, 15, 29, 43, 64 and Day 85, and at the 4-week follow-up phone call.

certainAgreement.otherDetails: Investigator may publish the study results, relative to his/her own patients, only after review, comment and approval by the sponsor. No publication of confidential information shall be made without the sponsor's prior written consent. At least 60 days prior to submitting a manuscript or prior to any public presentation, a copy of the manuscript or presentation will be provided to the sponsor for review and comment. The sponsor has 60 days to review and comment.

pointOfContact.title: James Youakim, Vice President, Clinical Development

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests pimavanserin 40 mg versus placebo in patients with Alzheimer’s disease psychosis. Pimavanserin is an antipsychotic that acts as an inverse agonist/antagonist at serotonin 5-HT2A receptors (with lesser 5-HT2C activity) and lacks dopamine D2 blockade — a mechanism aimed at reducing hallucinations/delusions rather than modifying Alzheimer’s pathology or directly improving cognition. citeturn1search4turn1search1

Act: Key extracted details — intervention: pimavanserin 40 mg (oral), comparator: placebo, population: patients with Alzheimer’s disease psychosis; intended effect: reduce psychotic symptoms (hallucinations/delusions). Pimavanserin has been studied for psychosis in Alzheimer’s/dementia populations (Phase II and other dementia-related psychosis studies) and is FDA-approved for hallucinations/delusions in Parkinson’s disease psychosis, supporting its use as a neuropsychiatric symptom treatment rather than a disease-modifying or cognitive-enhancing agent. citeturn0search5turn0search3turn0search4

Reflect: Classification — neuropsychiatric symptom improvement. The trial’s intervention and intended outcome (treatment of psychosis in AD) match the category definition for neuropsychiatric symptom improvement. This is not a disease-targeted biologic or small molecule aimed at Alzheimer’s pathology, nor a general cognitive enhancer. Note: pimavanserin carries warnings about increased mortality risk in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis (as do antipsychotics broadly), and it is not FDA-approved for dementia-related psychosis outside Parkinson’s disease psychosis — relevant context for safety/regulatory interpretation. citeturn0search0turn1search5

Web search results (sources used): FDA safety review of Nuplazid (pimavanserin) postmarketing analysis; Acadia/press & FDA approval announcement for Nuplazid; Phase II data/press release for pimavanserin in Alzheimer’s disease psychosis (CTAD); New England Journal of Medicine trial data for pimavanserin in dementia-related psychosis; Pimavanserin prescribing information / mechanism of action summary (Drugs.com package insert, StatPearls, and supporting PubMed articles). citeturn0search0turn0search3turn0search5turn0search4turn1search4turn1search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests pimavanserin (Nuplazid) for psychosis in Alzheimer's disease. Pimavanserin is a selective serotonin inverse agonist/antagonist that preferentially targets 5-HT2A receptors (with lesser 5-HT2C activity) and is non‑dopaminergic — i.e., it acts on neurotransmitter receptors rather than on core AD pathologies like amyloid or tau. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Extracted details — intervention: pimavanserin 40 mg (oral) vs placebo; intended effect: reduce hallucinations/delusions (neuropsychiatric symptom improvement). Mechanism: 5-HT2A inverse agonist/antagonist (serotonin receptor modulation), supported by Phase II Alzheimer’s disease psychosis data and the drug’s approved indication for Parkinson’s disease psychosis. These facts map directly to the CADRO category for neurotransmitter receptors. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Reflect: Classification check — the intervention targets serotonin (a neurotransmitter) receptors (5-HT2A/2C), so the most specific CADRO match is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. Although the trial’s goal is symptomatic (neuropsychiatric) improvement rather than disease modification, CADRO classifies the drug by its biological target (serotonin receptors), not by symptomatic versus disease‑modifying intent. Note safety/regulatory context: pimavanserin has boxed warnings and FDA safety communications relevant to dementia-related populations. citeturn0search1turn0news12

Web search results (sources used): Acadia Phase II data and mechanism summary (CTAD/Acadia press release). citeturn0search0; FDA safety review and prescribing information for Nuplazid (pimavanserin). citeturn0search1; Acadia press releases about Phase III/HARMONY and program rationale. citeturn0search3; Recent news about late‑stage trial outcomes and company program decisions. citeturn0news12turn0news13
